Introduction

Marfan syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder primarily affecting the cardiovascular, musculoskeletal, and ocular systems.  Early recognition and management are critical due to the risk of life-threatening complications such as aortic dissection.

Pathophysiology

Marfan syndrome most often results from an autosomal dominant mutation of the gene that encodes fibrillin-1, a major component of microfibrils that supports elastic fibers and helps maintain connective tissue integrity.

Fibrillin-1 is found throughout the musculoskeletal and cardiovascular systems (eg, aorta, mitral valve) as well as in the zonular fibers that suspend the ocular lens in place.  Normally, fibrillin-1 binds to and inactivates transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta), a protein that contributes to the degradation of elastic fibers and other extracellular matrix components by activating matrix metalloproteinases (

figure 1
).  Defective fibrillin-1 in Marfan syndrome is unable to bind to TGF-beta, resulting in excess free, active TGF-beta, fragmentation of elastic fibers, and decreased collagen density.

Manifestations involving the cardiovascular system carry the highest morbidity and mortality:

  • Within the aorta, defective fibrillin causes fragmentation and loss of the elastic lamellae with fibrosis and cystic medial degeneration (
    image 1
    ).  Collagen, elastin, and smooth muscle are replaced by a basophilic mucoid extracellular matrix with irregular fiber cross-linkages and cystic collections of mucopolysaccharide, allowing for dilation of the aortic root. 
  • Within the mitral valve, this process results in pooling of glycosaminoglycans (myxomatous mitral degeneration) and elongated, floppy mitral valve leaflets that prolapse into the atrium. 

Clinical presentation

Patients with Marfan syndrome are often recognized based on characteristic phenotypic features involving the musculoskeletal system; however, these findings are not always present, particularly in young children.  Additional manifestations (eg, cardiovascular, ocular), both acute and chronic, should raise suspicion for Marfan syndrome:

Musculoskeletal 

  • Tall, slender build with an increased arm span to height ratio (Marfanoid body habitus (
    figure 2
    ))
  • Reduced upper to lower segment ratio
  • Pectus excavatum/carinatum
  • Scoliosis/kyphosis
  • Arachnodactyly (long fingers); "thumb sign" (
    image 2
    ) and "wrist sign" (
    image 3
    )
  • Joint hypermobility (
    figure 3
    )
  • Dolichocephaly (long, narrow head), enophthalmos (sunken eyes), downslanting palpebral fissures, malar hypoplasia, and retrognathia

Cardiovascular

  • Aortic disease
    • Aortic root dilation is asymptomatic and typically found on echocardiography when performed for other features concerning for Marfan syndrome. 
    • Aortic regurgitation due to aortic root dilation causes a decrescendo diastolic murmur heard best along the right sternal border; this contrasts with valvular aortic regurgitation, which is heard best at the left third intercostal space.
    • Aortic dissection (usually involving ascending aorta and occurring before age 40) (
      figure 4
      ) typically manifests with sudden-onset, severe chest or back pain and may be the presenting symptom.  Patients who are pregnant and have Marfan syndrome have an increased risk for dissection as compared to those with either condition alone.
  • Mitral valve prolapse:  Midsystolic click with a mid-to-late systolic apical murmur heard best at the apex of the heart

Ocular

  • Lens dislocation (ectopia lentis) is caused by detachment from the ciliary body (often after no or minimal trauma) and presents with iridodonesis (tremulous iris) and painless vision loss.  The dislocation is typically upward in Marfan syndrome (
    image 4
    ).
  • Severe myopia (nearsightedness) due to globe elongation

Pulmonary

  • Spontaneous pneumothorax due to abnormal connective tissue within lung parenchyma, predisposing to apical blebs and bullae

Integumentary

  • Skin striae

Initial evaluation

Patients with multiple phenotypic features of Marfan syndrome or isolated ectopia lentis following minimal or no trauma should prompt evaluation, including the following:

  • Echocardiography
  • Ophthalmologic evaluation, including slit lamp examination
  • Genetic testing to identify a fibrillin-1 mutation

Those with type A aortic dissection age <60 also warrant genetic testing.

Diagnosis 

In patients with no family history of Marfan syndrome, one of the following criteria is diagnostic:

  • A fibrillin-1 mutation in the setting of either aortic dissection/dilation OR aortic aneurysm plus ectopia lentis
  • Aortic dissection/dilation plus either ectopia lentis OR other significant systemic findings (eg, pectus deformity, thumb sign)

In patients with a family history of Marfan syndrome, the presence of aortic dissection/dilation, ectopia lentis, or a constellation of other significant systemic findings are diagnostic.

Differential diagnosis

  • Ehlers-Danlos syndromes (
    üìä View Table: table 1
    ):  a group of connective tissue disorders that can have manifestations involving the musculoskeletal (eg, hypermobile joints), cardiovascular (eg, mitral valve prolapse), and ocular systems (eg, myopia).  However, most patients have hyperextensible skin; a tall, slender build with an increased arm span-to-height ratio is not expected.
  • Homocystinuria (
    üìä View Table: table 2
    ):  a defect in cystathionine synthase causes increased serum and urine homocysteine concentrations.  It is associated with a Marfanoid body habitus (eg, long limbs, pectus excavatum) and ectopia lentis.  Distinguishing features of homocystinuria include intellectual disability and a lens that is displaced downward rather than upward.
  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B:  Patients may have a Marfanoid habitus, but this condition is due to a hereditary RET protooncogene mutation that predisposes patients to the development of endocrine tumors (eg, medullary thyroid œ≤–∞n—Åer, —Äh–µŒøœ≤hrŒømŒøœ≤—Ét–æma) as well as mucosal neuromas (
    image 5
    ).
  • Klinefelter syndrome (
    figure 5
    ):  nondisjunction of the X chromosome results in a 47,XXY karyotype.  Patients typically have tall stature with increased risk for cardiac complications, such as ischemic heart disease and mitral valve prolapse.  Aortic root disease and other widespread connective tissue problems are not seen.

Complications and management

Cardiovascular

  • Prevention & monitoring:  Echocardiography is recommended at the time of diagnosis and 6 months later to assess the presence and progression of aortic root size, aortic valve function, and mitral valve prolapse.  Serial cross-sectional imaging (CT or MRI) is recommended for monitoring of aortic disease (eg, dissection, dilation, aneurysm (
    figure 6
    ); monitoring frequency may be increased during times of increased risk (eg, pregnancy).  Patients are counseled to avoid strenuous physical activity, including intense/contact sports (eg, track, basketball, football), if aortic root disease or a family history of aortic dissection or sudden death is present.
  • Pharmacotherapy:  Beta-blockers (eg, propranolol) or angiotensin II receptor blockers (eg, losartan) are recommended to decrease myocardial contractility and reduce the stress on the aortic wall.
  • Surgery:  Aortic root surgery is indicated for significant risk of aortic dissection or rupture (eg, rapidly enlarging aortic root diameter).  Mitral valve repair is indicated in cases of severe mitral regurgitation.

Musculoskeletal

  • Orthopedic interventions (eg, physical therapy, bracing, surgery) help manage issues such as scoliosis, pectus deformities, or joint dislocations.

Ocular

  • Corrective glasses/contacts are used to treat myopia, and surgery may be needed for ectopia lentis.
  • Annual ophthalmologic evaluations, including slit lamp examination, are recommended to identify and monitor the progression of ocular issues.

Pulmonary

  • Regular auscultation of the lungs to monitor for signs of spontaneous pneumothorax.
  • Scuba diving should be avoided due to risk of barotrauma-induced pneumothorax.

Genetic

Genetic counseling and testing should be offered to first-degree relatives of individuals with Marfan syndrome.

Prognosis

The most common cause of death in Marfan syndrome is aortic root disease complications (eg, dissection, ruptured aneurysm).  Heart failure can occur secondary to severe mitral valve prolapse or aortic regurgitation.

With proper cardiovascular management, patients with Marfan syndrome can have a normal life expectancy.

Summary

Marfan syndrome (

üìä View Table: table 3
) is caused by an autosomal dominant fibrillin-1 mutation, affecting connective tissue throughout the body, particularly within the musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular systems.  Classic findings include Marfinoid habitus, joint hypermobility, and upward lens dislocation.  Aortic root disease is the most common cause of mortality; serial imaging of the aortic root and surgical intervention help reduce life-threatening complications (eg, aortic dissection).
